availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

ab.bibl:
Tyler G. Anbinder, Nativism and Slavery: The Northern Know Nothings and the Politics of the 1850s (New York: Oxford University Press, 1992).
Charles E. Deusner, “The Know Nothing Riots in Louisville,” Register of the Kentucky Historical Society, vol. 61 (1963), 122-147.
Agnes Geraldine McGann, Nativism in Kentucky to 1860 (Washington, DC: Catholic University of America Press, 1944).
James McPherson, Battle Cry of Freedom: The Civil War Era, paperback (New York: Oxford University Press, 2003), 140-144, 153-157, 188.
Emmet V. Mittlebeeler, “The Aftermath of Louisville’s Bloody Monday Election Riot of 1855,” Filson Club History Quarterly, vol 66 (1992), 197-219.
William Darrell Overdyke, The Know-Nothing Party in the South (Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 1950).
James A. Ramage and Andrea S. Watkins, Kentucky Rising: Democracy, Slavery, and Culture from the Early Republic to the Civil War (Lexington: The University Press of Kentucky, 2011), 95-96.
